When you expect an "error" status, the "allow_access" call does not raise a BuildError exception.
If you remove this expectation (the default expected status is "active"), the method raises a BuildError if it goes to "error"

can we add a note or fixme that this should be revisited when [0] is merged at some point. this should cared for in the image so we don't need to do a configmap workaround

[0] https://github.com/grafana/helm-charts/pull/297

For downstream consumption it is likely going to be a different image - regardless if the proxy info is build in. Even if we submit a different PR to add proxy configuration, this logic should still be revisited.

I'm not following how overriding the image removes needing this.

Are you suggesting that in the future we'd be building an image with proxy setup before deploying Loki? And then providing that built image as an override to Loki?

If we're not aiming to build an image to deploy Loki then this would still have to exist because the test script always do an `apk add jq curl`, which would need a proxy to check for updates even if jq and curl were installed, if I understand correctly.

Better, would probably be to make another pull request adding in proxy configuration in the Loki helm chart.

I'm seeing the linked pull request and this behind the proxy work as two separate efforts with maybe some overlap, but I'm not seeing the image override as a solution for both problems by itself.

sysinv/cgts-client/cgts-client/cgtsclien.message: consider passing an additional optional argument, something like '?directive=remove&force=True'

This can be done but wasn't my first preference in "remove's" case unlike "delete" because:
remove calls _update which converts to a patch call in sysinv-api side. This patch function is used by other operation like "system application-apply" therefore changing the function definition from:
  def patch(self, name, directive, values)
to:
  def patch(self, name, directive, force="False", values)

felt unnecessary since the "values" variable was present for this kind of information passing via body. Hence, I'm more inclined to leveraging the existing mechanism instead of changing the function definition which is also used by other operation.

Also, in case of delete below, I sorted to this query passing mechanism which i didn't for remove above because in case of delete there is no existing mechanism to pass values, therefore, which ever I choose it didn't matter. More so because delete function in sysinv-api side is not that wildly used unlike patch by other operation. Hence, I choose the simple one which is passing information via query passing mechanism

I think I'd prefer a consistent URL pattern across the patch [apply, remove, abort] and delete commands so if someone was using the API directly (i.e. via curl) then executing a force of a given command is consistent.
consider making this '?force=<value>' and could always pass a True/False value making the conditional unnecessary.
consider dropping the conditional and always just passing args.force as a second parameter

I am not sure about this. Is there ever a case where JUJU_REMOTE_UNIT == JUJU_UNIT_NAME?

Based on what I see in the newly added functionality (as of Juju 2.8), there is a new environment variable exposed called JUJU_DEPARTING_UNIT which can be equal to the local unit name (JUJU_UNIT_NAME) but it doesn't look like it affects JUJU_REMOTE_UNIT.

https://github.com/juju/juju/blob/juju-2.8.0/worker/uniter/relation/resolver.go#L173-L185
https://github.com/juju/juju/blob/juju-2.8.0/worker/uniter/runner/context/context.go#L1009-L1013
https://github.com/juju/juju/commit/5a978061e1c031f6b4f38475696b5ed352fc39b0
https://github.com/juju/juju/commit/23e9e6270a7
The latest version of the patch uses the previously described approach.

When running "juju remove-unit" for a principal related with hacluster this is how the relevante JUJU_* environment variable look:

root@juju-60ffb3-2:/var/lib/juju/agents/unit-hacluster-1/charm# env | grep JUJU_
JUJU_UNIT_NAME=hacluster/1
JUJU_RELATION_ID=hanode:1
JUJU_DEPARTING_UNIT=hacluster/1
JUJU_VERSION=2.8.5
JUJU_PRINCIPAL_UNIT=percona-cluster/2
JUJU_REMOTE_UNIT=hacluster/0
JUJU_HOOK_NAME=hanode-relation-departed
JUJU_RELATION=hanode
JUJU_REMOTE_APP=hacluster
JUJU_DISPATCH_PATH=hooks/hanode-relation-departed

So it is correct that JUJU_REMOTE_UNIT == JUJU_UNIT_NAME won't happen during the execution of hanode-relation-departed hook.

We could make this patch work for juju>=2.8 taking advantage of JUJU_DEPARTING_UNIT and users running juju<=2.7 would need to run the 'update-ring' action, I believe this is a lot better than the current situation is.

Thoughts?
This comment is still worth addressing/answering. Indeed looking at the log, this code-path is never executed.

This `remote_unit() != principal_unit()` logic in a relation hook probably calls for future refactoring since it does not make sense outside of the broader context. What it means is that a relation hook for the container-scoped relationship (primary to subordinate) can be called from a different relation hook (in our case, the hanode-relation-changed hook) since normally for a container-scoped relationship it is always the case that JUJU_REMOTE_UNIT == JUJU_PRINCIPAL_UNIT.

I found that for a departing unit itself, there are as many <relname>-relation-departed hooks executed where JUJU_DEPARTING_UNIT == JUJU_UNIT_NAME as there are remote units (there's also a Juju bug about those not being represented via multiple entries in the status log https://bugs.launchpad.net/juju/+bug/1916746).

https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/charm-hacluster/+/741592/25/hooks/utils.py#1622

The reason it doesn't fail during functional testing is probably due to the fact that pcmk.commit(cmd) is called with a default argument value for failure_is_fatal (==False):

https://review.opendev.org/plugins/gitiles/openstack/charm-hacluster/+/3ee12babc1a8d9168d73ec6b68ccabf631ed4bc3/hooks/pcmk.py#58

We should probably make this properly idempotent without silently ignoring non-zero exit codes.

After another debugging session, here is what I discovered:

1. remove_corosync_node()'s command 'crm_node --force -R <node-name>' always fails (prints 'Connection to crmd failed: Connection refused (111)' and exits 201) because we stop corosync just before. Even a simple `sudo crm status` fails in the same way at this point.
2. If I don't stop corosync just before that command, it succeeds and seems to be idempotent, unfortunately it has no real effect: the corosync ring remains wrong if we don't run the `update-ring` action.

So I'm going to ditch this part as I think this review is complex enough. It will then always be necessary to run the `update-ring` action, which was the original intent of this review anyway. This can be revisited in a follow-up review if need be.

nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py.message: Looks good.  As discussed on IRC, even if the JSON file descriptors only check for Q35, it's good that we, Nova, too have a guard for it.
This should probably go into '_check_secure_boot_support'. Will move if I respin (and remember)

Actually, I need to keep this here since it's not specific to the secure boot stuff. We also require it to get a loader (since loaders are arch and machine-type specific). That's the cause of the failure in the preceding patch
Yup agreed and replace the raise with return False right?

Hmm, I'm not quite comfortable with this — in the "optional" case we should default to normal / UEFI boot (or even better SeaBIOS). It's a more "conservative" approach.

My worry is about "move operations"—which can be buggy / less (or not at all) tested with secure boot: because of the NVRAM file getting reset on some occasions, see[1].  An operator might get bitten accidentally.

(For cases where some explicitly requests secure boot, I'd expect them to understand that there'll be some trade-offs to accept—like move operations.)

[1] https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1633447 ("nova stop/start or reboot --hard resets uefi nvram")

If we did that, 'optional' would be exactly the same as 'disabled' and becomes meaningless. 'optional' isn't the default - that's 'disabled' - so if a user has specifically requested 'optional' then they're saying "give me secure boot if you can, but I don't care if you don't" along with all the negatives that having UEFI has

Right; on thinking more, that's a fair response.  As the default is disabled.  It is not unreasonable to expect from those going the "optional" route read a little bit of documentation.  We can't put a guard against every potential foot-gun.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
I'm still learning s3 api, but I wonder if we could make people use the `x-amz-expected-bucket-owner` if they want to privide their own Origin info from their container. We'd probably have to default the header to be returned in all s3 based cors Access-Control-Allow-Header field though.

If they don't then it defaults to what you say. It might mean we can still give some usefulness.. though I'm not sure how the s3 clients will allow users to do this. Just random brain storming.

The trouble is that devs have no control over the OPTIONS request -- the browser is responsible for making it before even attempting to to send any dev-specified data.

I guess *maybe* we could try to push devs to always include a header like

 x-bucket-owner-<access-id>: <some ignored value>

so the preflight always includes something like

 access-control-allow-headers: ..., x-bucket-owner-<access-id>, ...

but that knee-caps "simple" CORS requests that wouldn't otherwise need a preflight (or pushes a bunch of complexity on the client to know when the header is necessary and when it isn't).

The *right* fix looks a lot more like globally-unique bucket names. (Probably with some alternate s3 endpoint, like http://unique-buckets.fqdn instead of http://swift.fqdn, even if both host names resolve to the same pool of proxies.)

swift/common/middleware/s3api/s3api.py.message: why isn't this handled by making a request instance and catching NotS3Request as below for other methods?

The OPTIONS request will never "look like" an S3 request -- it won't have an Authorization header or any query params. (Note that Access-Control-Allow-Headers may mention an Authorization header, though.)

Speaking of query params, this probably still won't allow pre-signed PUTs 🤔
what happened to OPTIONS requests before the change above?
They'd raise NotS3Request, continue down the pipeline, and fail with a 400: https://github.com/openstack/swift/blob/2.26.0/swift/proxy/server.py#L524-L526

cinderclient.api_versions._get_server_version_range() using  cinderclient.v3.services.ServiceManager.server_api_version() using cinderclient.base.Manager._get_with_base_url() using cinderclient.client.<Client>.get_with_base_url() with is implemented only in SessionClient and absent in HTTPClient which is used in horizon.

This would force someone to have to go onsite to manually reconfigure the BMC with a crash cart, and while ugly, this could get completely out of hand if many servers were being deployed in parallel.

This specification covers two (2) aspects of hardware provisioning, BIOS and RAID, which ironic presently supports. It proposes to express the configuration of those in ironic terms and, on provisioning success, have the same side effects on the ironic node. The node's cached BIOS configuration and 'raid_config' field are the side effects for BIOS and RAID, respectively. Additionally, to support provisioning beyond what is defined by ironic, but which systems and their hardware types could offer in a vendor-specific manner, OEM configuration is also proposed.

Please see the changes made to the "Solution" subsection above which further describe what is being proposed and the idrac hardware type MVP.

what happens when OEM section errors out? What happens to already configured imported BIOS and RAID sections?

This section covers the format of the system configuration template. Please see the section above that discusses the import_configuration step, "Import configuration". It starts on line 151.

That section describes the import configuration workflow on lines 186-195, including what occurs when an error is encountered -- "clean/deploy step fails". On failure, no assurances can be made about the state of the system's configuration nor side effects on the ironic node fields, because the application of the configuration is system and ironic hardware type dependent and there are many possible failure modes. TL;DR, a defined configuration sequence and transactional rollback semantics do not seem to apply.

When a step fails, the ironic node is placed in the "clean failed" or "deploy failed" state and the node's 'last_error' field may contain further information about the cause of the failure.

Please see the change made to the "Import configuration" section.

specs/approved/fast-track-provisioning.r.message:
I have an issue with an API user being able to specify an arbitrary name for the end file to be saved on a server. Considering that "user" could actually be an attacker that wants to potentially perform harmful actions.

Use of an intermediate temp directory for this also doesn't really provide any security or prevent such as an attacker could potentially work to escape the folder depending on the file name.

To make things even worse, Operating System security controls may preserve the security context of a file written to a temporary folder that is then copied or moved elsewhere.

A far more secure solution is for random file names to be used on sever, and those files can either have some sort of name, or ironic simply just returns "where" a user can find it in something such as Swift using semi-random filename.

To provide clarity into just how strongly I feel about this, I'm borderline -2 on the user definable filename being used as the on-disk filename from a security and operational standpoint.
Addressing this in main thread about storage security.
I am not sure how it's useful by saving the configuration file into local filesystem, someone would need to locate the conductor and get it from there.

author.status: On the moon! With a jetpack!

specs/approved/fast-track-provisioning.r.message: The path should be either directly to disk in some way/shape/form or directly to swift in some way/shape/form. Intermediate stops increase the number of IO operations which is not ideal performance wise. Not to temp folder and then swift as this is somewhat implying.
This is only here because current Swift API in Ironic expects files https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic/src/branch/master/ironic/common/swift.py#L100

This kind of leads to my preference that we avoid the problem of storage for external user interaction.
